editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).

div.head: To the Right Honourable and mo≈øt reuerend Father, the Lord Archbi≈øhop of Canterburie, Primate of all England, and one of her Maie≈øties mo≈øt honorable priuie Councell, his verie good Lord; Thomas Sparke wi≈øheth all health, happine≈ø≈øe, and pro≈øperitie to his owne heartes good contentation and comfort.
div.p:
MAnie and ≈øundrie fauours and kindne≈ø≈øes (Right Honorable and right reuerende in the Lord) for the≈øe twentie yeares ≈øpace that I haue knowne yow, receiued at your Graces hands, haue alwaies made me not onely to loue and reuerence yow; but al≈øoe to thinke my ≈øelfe vnfainedly ≈øoe much bounde and beholden vnto your Grace, as that I haue a long time

beene of this minde, that it is not ≈øufficient to di≈øcharge me of vnthankfulne≈ø≈øe, by bare wordes (though neuer ≈øo ful of kindne≈ø≈øe & thankefulne≈ø≈øe) both in your ab≈øence and pre≈øence to te≈øtifie the ≈øame, (whereof yet euer ≈øince I fir≈øt knew you I haue beene carefull and mindefull) and therefore I haue long agoe re≈øolued my ≈øelfe (hauing no better meanes to doe it by,) by dedicating ≈øome part of my poore labours vnto you, to giue you and all others, to whom the ≈øight thereof ≈øhall come, ≈øome publike and a≈ø≈øured te≈øtimonie of my duetifull and thankefull heart towardes you. Whereupon hauing at the earne≈øt and importunate ≈øute and reque≈øt of diuers of my wor≈øhipfull and good friendes, not long ≈øince committed to writing the Treati≈øe following (which
in effect they first heard me from point to point in this manner deliuer vnto them in certeine ≈øermons) I haue now thought it good in this ≈øort ≈øomewhat enlarged to publi≈øh it, the better to ≈øatisfie their de≈øires: and to the end afore≈øaid, I haue made bolde to dedicate the ≈øame vnto your Grace, be≈øeeching you to accept therof rather according to the minde of the offerer (which I prote≈øt vnto you is full of loue and reuerence towardes you,) than to the ≈øimplicitie & meane≈ø≈øe of the thing it ≈øelfe, which I mu≈øt needes confe≈ø≈øe in respect of the handling, is much vnworthie of ≈øuch an Honourable patrone as your ≈øelfe is. As for the matter, it is (I am per≈øwaded) an≈øwerable to the title that I haue giuen it, which is, The high way to Heauen. For therin
fir≈øt is ≈øhewed howe the lawe is our ≈øchoolemai≈øter to Chri≈øt, by cau≈øing vs to knowe our ≈øinnes, and to feele the weight and burthen thereof to make vs wearie of the ≈øame, and therefore to hunger and thir≈øt after him: and then what Chri≈øt is in per≈øon and office, and how he is to be apprehended and fed on to ≈øaluation by a true and liuely ≈øaith in him, is largely & plainlie declared: and lastly al≈øo, heerein ≈øuch as are and haue beene fir≈øt duely throwen downe by the lawe, and after truelie rai≈øed vp againe by the Go≈øpel, in Christ, are taught how they are to liue and ≈øpend the re≈øt of their daies in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. Which I am ≈øure is the olde ancient beaten waie throughout all the whole cour≈øe of the olde and new Testament, and in
all ≈øound antiquitie, that the ≈øaints and ≈øeruantes of God haue taken to be the onelie ≈øaife and ≈øure wace, wherby they haue ≈øought to come to the kingdom of heauen. Your Grace therfore being one (as I fullie per≈øwade my ≈øelfe you are) that ≈øeeke to come thither by this onelie waie, and therefore one al≈øo that is verie de≈øirous that all others ≈øhould walke thitherwards in an eauen and ≈øtreight cour≈øe therunto; in re≈øpect of the matter therein handled, my good hope is, you will not be a≈øhamed or thinke much at all, that it ≈øeeketh thus to come abroad vnder your countenance & protection. For though the waie be neuer ≈øo well knowne alreadie and be beaten and trode out by manie before this, and that perhaps more exactly and ≈øub≈øtantially than it is herein
in by me: yet ≈øeeing manie are ≈øtill to go this ≈øame way, & all cannot hit of the ≈øame guids, & still Sathan wil be bu≈øie by his complices eyther to keepe men froÃÑ finding it, or by one ≈øleight or other to turne them out of it. I tru≈øt that after ≈øo manie that haue gone before me in guiding men into and keeping them in this way, this my profered ≈øeruice to that end, may & will bee yet profitable vnto many. Now the≈øe 24. years at the lea≈øt it hath plea≈øed the Lord to v≈øe my poore mini≈øtrie, and that, his name be ble≈ø≈øed for it, in great peace & quietne≈øse, & yet I haue therin alwaies bene of this mind, and am & will be ≈øtil, not to e≈øteeme or know anie thing, but euen this way through Ie≈øus Christ and him crucified. 1. Cor. 2.2. And ≈øure I am I find and I per≈øwade my ≈øelfe I ≈øhall still,
though I coÃÑtinued therin twi≈øe as long more, this to be a matter ≈øo nece≈ø≈øarie and of that importance beyond all other, to be in≈øi≈øted in and dwelt vpon, that I ≈øhould neuer haue either lea≈øure or plea≈øure to trouble eyther pre≈ø≈øe or pulpit with any thing without the verie bondes and ≈øtrict limites hereof. For (alas) euery where, yea euen where mo≈øt paines hath bene taken and yet is by catechi≈øing of & conference with the people, yea by view of their liues, there is eyther ≈øuch gro≈ø≈øe ignorance heereof, or erring or halting heerein to be found & ≈øeene among≈øt theÃÑ, that if all the ministers of England had the tongues both of men and Angels, they ≈øhould find work inough throughlie to employ them≈øelues in, onelie about the reformation heereof. I would
to God therfore, that all controuer≈øies, wherof men may be ignorant without danger either of not finding, or of not lea≈øing this heauenly way, might either be kept and re≈øerued onely to brotherly and friendlie conferences among the godlie learned, or el≈øe that for euer they might be faire dead and buried among≈øt vs; and that ≈øo, that all of vs as one man with one heart and with one mind, might & would ioyne all our forces together to leade men aright into this waie, and to keepe them on streight in the ≈øame, what ≈øubtiltie and cunning ≈øoeuer Sathan and his in≈øtrumentes ≈øhould at anie time v≈øe to the contrarie. For we may be ≈øure, ≈øo that he any way can get men to mi≈øse or to lea≈øe this waie whiles we are bu≈øying our owne heades and the peoples with
other matters of farre le≈ø≈øe importance, though therein we ≈øhew neuer ≈øo much zeale and learning, he hath the verie thing he de≈øireth. For that doubtle≈ø≈øe hath beene and is ≈øtill a dangerous ≈øtratageme or pollicie of his, when he findeth he cannot as he would preuaile by keeping men in ignorance and carele≈ø≈øe ≈øecurity, then to doe what he can, that they may ≈øpend their learning and zeale about matters of the lea≈øt moment; that in the meane time he may the more quietlie by their ≈øilence in matters of greate≈øt weight, by the other contrary way, as it were paue the waie to Athei≈øme: yea I feare much (to ≈øpeake plainely what I thinke) that lacke of due con≈øideration hereof in time, in ≈øome hath not onelie beene one of the next cau≈øes of the phanta≈øticall
≈øectes of the Browni≈øtes, and Famili≈øtes, but al≈øo of too ≈øhamefull encrea≈øe, in ≈øo great light of the Go≈øpell, both of Papistes and Atheistes amonge≈øt vs. Wherefore my heartes de≈øire and prayer to God for England is and euer ≈øhall be, and for all the Churches of Chri≈øt where≈øoeuer in the wide world, that this ≈øubtiltie of Sathan may both heere and euerie where be throughlie well lookt vnto, and the mi≈øchiefe thence en≈øuing be as carefully preuented as po≈ø≈øiblie may be: for otherwi≈øe it may growe intollerable and vncurable. And J be≈øeech the Lord heartilie to giue your Grace and all the re≈øt of the reuerend Fathers the Bi≈øhops of this land, and all others that be in authoritie with you in the ≈øame, both skill
and will, power and might by the a≈ø≈øi≈øtance of his holie ≈øpirite ≈øpeedilie and effectuallie to clean≈øe and purge the≈øe Churches of England and Ireland ≈øo, of all the≈øe foure kindes of dangerous aduer≈øaries, that without their ≈øtopping of vs at the first, or ≈øeducing of vs afterward eyther of the right hand or of the left, all the re≈øt of vs as brethren and heires of the kingdom of heauen may both happilie get into this way thither, and al≈øo mo≈øt ≈øtedfa≈øtlie and constantlie per≈øeuere therein euen vnto the verie end.

Thus pre≈øuming (as you ≈øee) of your Graces curteous and friendlie acceptance both of this my trauell in pointing out this waie, and al≈øo of this my bold dedicating the ≈øame vnto you: J will not cea≈øe to praie vnto God to
requite and recompence ≈øeauen-folde into your bo≈øome both this & all your great and vnde≈øerued former fauours towardes mee. And thus be≈øeeching him al≈øo long to pre≈øerue you in health and honour to his glorie, the Churches good, & to your owne euerla≈øting comfort now & euer; crauing al≈øo pardon for this my boldnes, and hoping therof, I mo≈øt humblie take my leaue. div.p:
IN the≈øe wordes (welbeloued in our Lorde and Sauiour) the holy Euangeli≈øt Saint Iohn hath ≈øet down the ≈øumme and effect of a famous ≈øermon made by Chri≈øt him≈øelfe, the verie con≈øideration whereof, ought both to ≈øtirre vppe me to open the ≈øame the more reuerently,
and al≈øo to prooue you, to li≈øten thereunto the more religiou≈øly and attentiuely. Herein, The method. the method that he hath followed, and that therefore likewi≈øe I mu≈øt, is this; Fir≈øt, hee noteth certaine circum≈øtances thereof, then the ≈øub≈øtance of the ≈øermon it ≈øelfe. The circum≈øtances hee expre≈ø≈øeth in the≈øe wordes, Nowe in the la≈øt and greate day of the fea≈øt, Ie≈øus ≈øtood and cryed ≈øaying: and the ≈øermon in the re≈øt: and that in this order. Fir≈øt he noteth to whom he directed it, and his ≈øpeech therein, ≈øaying that he beganne it thus, If any man thir≈øt: then in the re≈øt, what it was that he ≈øpake vnto ≈øuch: Nowe the ≈øumme of his ≈øpeeches (as he hath heere recorded it) con≈øi≈øted of two pointes: fir≈øt of a commaundement that he gaue to them to whome he ≈øpake, and then of a promi≈øe that he made them, obeying that commaundement of his. The commaundement the Euangeli≈øt ≈øaith, was this, Let him come to me and drinke: and the promi≈øe was this, hee that beleeueth in mee as ≈øaith the ≈øcripture, out of his belly ≈øhall flowe riuers of waters of life. So that he commaunded two thinges: fir≈øt a comming vnto him, and then a drinking of him: and fora≈ømuch as the promi≈øe was thus
deliuered in a figuratiue and metaphoricall kinde of phra≈øe, the Euangeli≈øt directed by the ≈øpiritte of God, of a care he had to leade men to the right vnder≈øtanding of Chri≈øtes meaning therein, and to pre≈øerue them from mi≈øtaking of the ≈øame, telleth vs plainely, that by the riuers of waters of life, that Chri≈øt ≈øpake of in this promi≈øe of his, he vnder≈øtoode, the ≈øpiritte which they that beleeued in him, ≈øhoulde receiue, adding withall, that that was not in ≈øuch mea≈øure yet powred vppon ≈øuch, as it ≈øhoulde be afterward, for that Ie≈øus was not yet glorified; for ≈øo his wordes, the holie Gho≈øt was not yet, mu≈øt be vnder≈øtoode as I ≈øhall ≈øhewe, The circuÃÑ ≈øtances. when I come vnto them. Wherefore nowe to pro≈øecute the≈øe thinges in order as they lie, as they ≈øhall offer them≈øelues vnto vs in the text. Fir≈øt we haue to con≈øider what he hath ≈øaide concerning the circircum≈øtances of this ≈øermon. Touching which, nowe in the la≈øt and greate daie of the fea≈øt, Ie≈øus ≈øtoode and cryed (≈øaith the Euangeli≈øt:) for the better vnder≈øtanding of which wordes, if we peru≈øe the former part of this Chapter, it will euidentlie appeare vnto vs, that when Chri≈øt made this ≈øermon, he was at Hieru≈øalem, and
in the temple there, by occa≈øion of the fea≈øt of tabernacles, which then there they kept & ≈øolemnized; where and when the Iewes ≈øought to take him, and therfore purpo≈øely the phari≈øies, and high prie≈øtes ≈øent officers thither, and that to the end that ≈øo he being taken, they might kill him, whereof Chri≈øt was not ignorant. For there before this, at this verie fea≈øt, teaching openly out of the ≈øcriptures, to the a≈øtoni≈øhment of all his enemies, that heard him, he ≈øaith ≈ølatly vnto them, ver≈ø. 19. Why goe yee about to kill me? Nowe the la≈øt day of this fea≈øt as we may ≈øee. Leuit. 23. ver≈ø. 36 was the eight day when by Gods ordinaÃÑce they were to haue an holie conuocation, and a ≈øolemne a≈ø≈øemblie: vpon which daie Ie≈øus ≈øtoode vp, and made this ≈øermon, with a lowde and crying voyce, that ≈øo the better he might be hearde throughout that great a≈ø≈øemblie and concour≈øe of people. All the≈øe thinges therefore laid together, ≈øhew vs plainely thus much, that Ie≈øus was the preacher of the ≈øermon, and where, when, and in what manner it was preached by him: namely, that it was preached at Hieru≈øalem, euen in the temple, at and in the fea≈øt of tabernacles, and vpon the la≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øolemne day therof,
and that in the midde≈øt of mo≈øt bloody, and malitious enemies; mo≈øt confidently, ≈øtoutly, and boldly, for he vttered it ≈øtanding and crying, thereby ≈øhewing that he was neither afraide to be heard nor ≈øeene: yea, thereby making it mo≈øt manife≈øt, that he de≈øired nothing more, then that they ≈øhoulde thorowly both ≈øee and knowe his per≈øon, and vnder≈øtand and beleeue his doctrine. And yet for all this, howe de≈øirous ≈øoeuer his enemies were, then to haue taken him, yet no man had power to lay handes on him, as it is noted: Ver≈øe. 44. yea they that were ≈øent to that ende, returned, and gaue this rea≈øon of their not touching him, that neuer man ≈øpake as he did, ver≈ø. 46. The noting thus of the≈øe circum≈øtances, by the Euangeli≈øt, wee mu≈øt not thinke was needle≈ø≈øe, but to very good purpo≈øe: yea, we ought alwaies to a≈ø≈øure our ≈øelues, how≈øoeuer in humane writings and ≈øpeeches, there may often be found many idle and ≈øuperfluous wordes, that it is neuor ≈øo in the Canonicall ≈øcriptures. For they beeing as they are, all en≈øpired of God, 2. Tim. 3. ver≈ø. 16, and the holy writers thereof, ≈øpeaking and writing therein onely, as they were mooued by the holie Gho≈øt, as Peter te≈øtifieth of
them, 2. Pet. ver≈ø. 21. we may be ≈øure they haue not vttered or ≈øet downe any word in vaine therein. And if we doe but a little weigh and con≈øider of tho≈øe circum≈øtances, thus ≈øet downe heere by ≈øaint Iohn how ≈øleight ≈øoeuer the v≈øe thereof ≈øeeme to vs at the fir≈øt we ≈øhall ≈øoone perceiue, that there is both much and very good v≈øe to be made thereof. For fir≈øt notwith≈øtanding the corruptions of tho≈øe times, in that Chri≈øt would come to Hieru≈øalem, to the fea≈øt of tabernacles, we may learne, not onely Chri≈øtes obedience to Gods ceremoniall lawe, as then yet ≈øtanding in force and not abrogated, to teach vs alwaies to be obedient to his perpetuall lawes: But al≈øo, that it is not lawfull, ≈øci≈ømaticallie (as Anabapti≈øtes, Browni≈øtes, and they of the familie of loue and others doe) to ≈øhunne publike a≈ø≈øemblies, and the exerci≈øes of true religion therein, for euery ≈ømall corruption and ≈øuper≈øtitious fa≈øhion, either but ≈øeeming to ≈øuch ≈øo to bee, or indeede which are ≈øo to be found therein. Becau≈øe that then both in the prie≈øtes and in their additions and detractions from the lawe of God, the corruptions were many, gro≈ø≈øe and euident, as the Euangeli≈øtes and ≈øtories of tho≈øe times, make it mo≈øt manife≈øt,

Whiles then we teach thus (as no otherwi≈øe wee doe,) doe we ≈øet open any gappe of libertie or licentiou≈ønes to our hearers, or are we in our doctrine any way enimies to good works, as our aduer≈øaries ≈ølander vs? Nay doe we not as earne≈øtly and vehemently, as they can for their liues, vrge men to doe them? Indeede we dare not teach them, when they haue done neuer ≈øo manie of them, in any ca≈øe to make any peece of a ≈øauiour, eyther of any thing they doe or ≈øuffer: becau≈øe, as you haue heard, we learned out of the Scriptures, that that office ≈øo intirely and wholly is to be referred to Chri≈øt, that it may not be imparted or communicated, without antichri≈øtian robbing of him of that ≈øpeciall honour that belongs vnto him, to anie thing or per≈øon el≈øe. But yet notwith≈øtanding, as now you heare, we mo≈øt plainely teach, that none can haue any certaintie in him≈øelfe (without which our faith is but a fruiteles wauering conceite
that as yet he is in Chri≈øt and ≈øhall be ≈øaued vndoubtedlie for his ≈øake, vntill the power of him dwelling in him, truelie appeare by the≈øe fruites of the ≈øpirite, that are heere for their puritie, multiplicitie, vtilitie, and continuance called riuers of water of life flowing out of the bellies of ≈øuch. And therefore though we dare not with our aduer≈øaries teach men, nor encourage men to doe good workes, either in part or in whole to earne, de≈øerue, or merit heauen by, (which vnle≈ø≈øe we would ≈øay with them, we ≈øay nothing to this purpo≈øe) yet mo≈øt cleare and euident it is, that to that end we v≈øe and vrge all the arguments that the Scriptures haue taught vs. For we be≈øeech them by the mercies of God with Paule. Rom. 12.1. to giue vp their bodies a liuing ≈øacrifice, holy and acceptable vnto God, in ≈øeruing him according to his word, and not according to the fa≈øhions of the world. For that by the≈øe tender mercies of God towardes vs in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, we that beleeue aright in him, are deliuered out of the hands of all our enemies, that we ≈øhould ≈øerue him without feare, all the daies of our life, in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe before him. Luke. 1.74.75. For in
that this grace of God, that bringeth ≈øaluation vnto all men, hath appeared, it teacheth vs that we ≈øhould denie vngodlines & worldly lu≈øts, & that we ≈øhould liue ≈øoberly, & righteou≈øly & godly in this pre≈øent world. Tit. 2.11.12. Yea hauing rightlie laid hold of this grace, we ≈øay againe with the ≈øame Paule, That we are Gods workeman≈øhip created in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus vnto good workes, which he hath ordained that we ≈øhoulde walke in Ephe≈ø. 2.10. Againe with Chri≈øt to this ende we ≈øay vnto all, Let your light ≈øo ≈øhine before men, that they may ≈øee your good workes and glorifie your Father which is in heauen. Matth. 5.16. and loue one another, as he hath loued vs: for by this ≈øhall all men knowe, that yee are his Di≈øciples, Iohn. 13.34.36. And with Peter, we exhorte all men to ioyne vertue to their faith, to their vertue knowledge, to their knowledge temperance, to their temperance, patience, to their patience godline≈ø≈øe, and to that botherlie kindene≈ø≈øe and loue, ≈øo to make their election ≈øure, 2. Peter. 1.5. & 6. With Iames al≈øo we crie and call vpon euerie one that maketh confe≈ø≈øion of faith, to ≈øhewe his faith by his workes, which if hee doe not,
we as plainely tell him with the ≈øame Iames, that his faith is deade in him≈øelfe. Iam. 2.17. &c. For the faith that auaileth in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, as Paul hath taught vs, worketh by loue, not that loue is in the forme of faith (for how can one di≈øtinct vertue be the forme of an other) but that it is the in≈øeperable companion of a liuely and ≈øound faith. Neither are we negligent in often laying before our people Gods law and the true meaning thereof, both to teach them what good workes are, and to incite them to doe the ≈øame. Wherein we dare be bould to ≈øay we goe beyond our aduer≈øaries, in leading men aright to good workes. For we vrge and ≈øhewe the lawe of GOD to be ≈øo perfect and ab≈øolute a rule of good workes, that it reacheth to the condemning of the fir≈øt motions ari≈øing in our mindes to ≈øinne, though they be not at all yeelded vnto and liked of, for that it calleth for the whole heart to be occupied onely in the things that plea≈øe GOD, and that all ≈øinne is condemned therein, and all vertue commended: whereas our aduer≈øaries the papi≈øtes, holde the lawe to be ≈øo imperfect, that
it condemneth not the≈øe fir≈øt motions to ≈øinne, and that there are a number of good workes, and as meritorious, that haue for their grounde but the traditions and commandements of men, as manie that are expre≈øly commaunded by the law of GOD: forgetting belike that the law is ≈øo ≈øpirituall, that it made Paule to crie out of him≈øelfe, O wretched man that I am, who shall deliuer mee from this bodie of ≈øinne and death? Rom. 7.24. and that Chri≈øt mo≈øt flatly hath ≈øaid, that they worship him in vaine that teach for doctrines mens preceptes. Math. 15.9. We v≈øe often to terrifie our hearers from ill workes, and from omitting of good, by making it manife≈øt vnto them, by the iudgements of GOD therefore threatned and executed, that ≈øo to doe, is ≈øo daingerous, as that thereby they de≈øerue all Gods heauie iudgments to be executed vpon them both in this life, and in the life to come: and that vndoubtedlye they ≈øhall, if they repent not. Wherein al≈øo we goe further than the≈øe our aduer≈øaries: for they teach that a number of ≈øinnes, euen for the littlenes thereof, are not deadly, or ≈øuch as de≈øerue damnation,
which may ea≈øily be ≈øatisfied for and put away. La≈øtly we forget not to teach them what promi≈øes of reward God hath made to ≈øuch as will carefully walke before him in holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe, both concerning this life, and that which to come; a≈ø≈øuring them with Paule, That godline≈ø≈øe is profitable vnto all thinges, and hath the promi≈øe hoth of this life pre≈øent, and of that which is to come. 1. Tim. 4.8. wherein we goe ≈øo farre that al≈øo with Chri≈øt we confidently tell them, that they ≈øhall not lea≈øe their rewarde in heauen, no not of a cup of colde water be≈øtowed aright in his name vpon any of his. Mat. 10.42. For though all that we doe or can doe, be infinitelie le≈ø≈øe than we owe to God and are bound to doe, (for in many things we ≈øinne all, Iam. 3.2.) yet all that approue them≈øelues to be in Chri≈øt by walking not after the fle≈øh but after the ≈øpirite in bringing forth the right fruites thereof, as Paule teacheth Rom. 8.12.13. &c. vndoubtedly for Gods promi≈øes ≈øake in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus, ≈øhall both heere and in heauen finde them≈øelues and their workes ≈øo liberally rewarded, that they ≈øhal haue no cau≈øe to complaine, but rather to wonder at Gods mo≈øt bountifull
crowning of his owne ble≈ø≈øinges and graces with further both heere and there. Thus then you ≈øee that though, when the que≈øtion is in hande why men ≈øhall be ≈øaued, we dare ≈øende them to no other meritorious cau≈øe thereof but onelie to Chri≈øt, and the thinges done by him≈øelfe for vs, becau≈øe we know that his name is the one lie name whereby commeth ≈øaluation, Act. 4.12; yet when it is demaunded who they are, which for Chri≈øtes ≈øake ≈øhall indeede be ≈øaued and ≈øo re≈øt in Gods tabernacle, and for euer dwell vpon his holy hill, we are boulde to teach that none but they that, according to the time and occa≈øion they haue after they be in him, proue them≈øelues to be ≈øuch by the riuers of water of life flowing out of their bellies, as you haue heard, and therefore are ≈øuch as are de≈øcribed to that ende, P≈øalm. 15.2. &c. And beeing ≈øuch, we counte it no pre≈øumption, but mo≈øt commendable faith in them to be fully per≈øwaded (becau≈øe they haue not onelie Gods worde and promi≈øe generally offered vnto them, and particularly ≈øealed in the admini≈øtration of the worde and Sacramentes outwardlie;
but al≈øo mo≈øt effectually inwardly te≈øtified vnto their ≈øpirites by Gods owne Spirit by the≈øe newe fruites thereof, to appertaine particularly vnto them, to ground this their per≈øwation vpon) that for Chri≈øtes ≈øake vndoubtedly they ≈øhal be ≈øaued. The≈øe arguments therefore, we doubt not, will bee ≈øufficient to moue and to per≈øwade all that vnfainedly be the Lordes, euen of loue and thankefulnes towardes him for his vn≈øpeakable loue and mercies towardes them, to ≈øtriue both day and night, by all po≈ø≈øible meanes, ≈øo to ≈øtirre vp the graces of the ≈øpirit in them, that indeede worthylie they may bee counted as Riuers of waters of life flowing out of their bellies.

Thus then at la≈øt (welbeloued in the Lorde) we haue hearde fir≈øt, the circum≈øtances of a notable ≈øermon made by Chri≈øt our Sauiour him≈øelfe, as where, when, vpon what occa≈øion, and in what manner he made it; namelie at Hieru≈øalem, in the temple, in and vpon the la≈øt and mo≈øt ≈øolemne day of the fea≈øt of Tabernacles, to draw them that were there, from their owne vaine
≈øuper≈øtitions that led them from him to him≈øelfe, vttered by him ≈øtanding, and that with a crying voice. Secondly you haue heard that he ≈øpoke therein to all that be thir≈øtie, and to none el≈øe, that is to all that are truely broken and contrite hearted vnder the burthen of their ≈øinnes, and ≈øo earne≈øtly long for redemption and deliuerance from the ≈øame. Thirdly you haue heard that he commaunded ≈øuch, what, to ea≈øe them of this their ≈øpirituall thir≈øt, they ≈øhoulde doe; and that that was, and is, fir≈øt to come vnto him, that is to know and acknowledge him what he is in per≈øon and office, and then to drinke of him, that is, rightlie to beleeue in him, and ≈øo thereby to make him, with all the mercies of God prouided for mans ≈øaluation in him, their owne: which they hauing done, la≈øtly you haue heard that he promi≈øeth all ≈øuch that his Spirit in them all ≈øhould be as riuers of water of life flowing out of their bellies, which was not, nor had not beene as yet then; becau≈øe when Chri≈øt made this ≈øermon, hee was not yet glorified. And in handling of all the≈øe, withall you haue beene ≈øhewed what we are to learne euerie one of
vs thereby, both mini≈øters and people, which haue beene ≈øuch and ≈øuch and ≈øo manie good thinges, as that if we haue heard as we ought to doe, we haue all of vs (I hope) euen ≈øufficiently to our ≈øaluation, learned both howe to beleeue and how to liue to be ≈øaued. For fir≈øt we haue beene taught howe by the lawe we are to be humbled and throwne downe, that we may be fit patients for Chri≈øt Ie≈øus ≈øecondly we haue heard by the Go≈øpell, how we are to ri≈øe againe and to recouer a better ≈øtanding than euer we had in the fir≈øt Adam, by knowledge and faith of the ≈øecond, Chri≈øt Ie≈øus our Lord and Sauiour. For we haue beene ≈øhewed how the Spirit of God by the mini≈øtrie of the worde and Sacramentes through this faith of ours, grounded vpon ≈øounde knowledge, vnites Chri≈øt Ie≈øus him≈øelfe and vs togither, though after a ≈øpirituall manner, yet mo≈øt truelie and effectually to our ≈øaluation, and the contrarie doctrine hath at large bene confuted. And by the way it hath mo≈øt plainely beene laide before vs, howe we ought to be qualified both in faith and manners, both in hearing of the
worde and in the v≈øe of the Sacraments, that thereby ≈øtill we may growe vp in the hou≈øe of GOD in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus to be perfect men, and acceptable in the ≈øight of his heauenlie father. La≈øtlie, by the viewe of the promi≈øe we haue beene (I tru≈øt) thorowlie taught what manner of liues we ought to leade, as long as we liue, after that once we bee got to be in Chri≈øt Ie≈øus indeede, in all true holine≈ø≈øe and righteou≈øne≈ø≈øe. God therefore of his infinite mercie for our Sauiour Chri≈øt Ie≈øus ≈øake giue vs grace ≈øo to imprint all the≈øe thinges in our harts, that to his owne glorie to the edifying of all others, amonge≈øt whom wee ≈øhall liue, and to the euerla≈øting comfort of our owne ≈øoules we may euerie one of vs that haue nowe hearde the≈øe thinges, both vnfainedlie beleeue and liue alwaies accordinglie. Nowe God the Father, God the Sonne, and God the holie Gho≈øt, three per≈øons and one GOD, to whome be a≈øcribed all honour, prai≈øe, and glorie nowe and for euer, be with all our ≈øoules and bodies, to ble≈ø≈øe, pre≈øerue and keepe vs ≈øo in
both this way, that wee all of vs liuing and dying may keepe a ≈øteddie and ≈øtreight cour≈øe therein vntill hee vouch≈øafe to take vs all hence to be heires of his eternall and euerla≈øting kingdome. Amen. Amen.
